It could be that your child is the only new student in the school and the school has not had time to get to know him. I would love to give you a recipe for paella, but I can't. Paella, as we know it today, is a bastardized dish that was created by Spanish-Americans during the 1950s. It was not created in Spain.
I'm sorry to be the bearer of bad news, but it's not even close to being a Spanish dish, nor is it a traditional dish. It's a dish that was created to make Spanish cuisine more palatable to Americans. It was the result of a marriage between Spanish and American cuisines. Spanish cooks never made paella with saffron, or with long, thin strands of meat.
In Spain, paella is a dish made from rice and Valencian or Murcian chicken (also known as "frankly chicken"). The chicken is either whole (one piece) or cut into small pieces and coated in oil, saffron, and garlic. The rice is cooked in olive oil, garlic, and saffron, and a little water, if necessary. Paella is a rice dish that originated in the Valencia region of Spain. It is popular in the Mediterranean region and is often eaten in Spain as a lunch dish. Traditionally, it is made in a large pan and is a very rustic dish. It can be made with many different types of seafood, poultry, or meat, but the most popular versions are made with rabbit, chicken, or seafood.
Paella has many different versions, but traditionally it is made with saffron, green beans, chorizo, and green peas, but sometimes it is made with artichokes and beans. The rice is sauteed in olive oil and then the other ingredients are added. It is usually topped with crumbled saffron.

There are various versions of paella, but all are rice-based dishes containing meat, fish, shellfish, vegetables and spices.
The word “paella” comes from the Latin word “patella,” meaning pan, because this is the pan in which the dish is prepared.
Today, the most popular type of paella is Valencian paella, made with rabbit, chicken and white beans, but there are also seafood and vegetable versions.
It is cooked on a wood or gas grill over a large fire. Traditionally, a dough-like paste made of water, rice and other ingredients is stirred into the pan over the fire. Once the rice is cooked, the fire is put out and the liquid and rice are removed from the pan and served in large shallow bowls.
The original recipe was a one-pot dish made of rice, chicken, rabbit and snails, but nowadays a variety of ingredients are used, such as beans, shrimp, lobster, squid, clams, mussels and tomatoes.

continuation:
I am interested in trying some Catalonian dishes. Can you give me a recipe for paella?
Paella is a popular rice dish from the region of Valencia in Spain. The recipe is really quite simple and can be tailored to your taste. As I am not a huge fan of vegetables, I would not include them in my version. To make a classic Paella, I would start by sautéing some chopped chorizo (which can be found in the deli section of most grocery stores) and add some shrimp. The next thing I would do is add some chicken, and finally some chicken stock. I would add some saffron, then add the rice, and cook everything for about 20 minutes. The rice should be cooked, but still be moist. Add some peas and serve. You can add some white wine if you like, or a squeeze of lemon. Paella is also really good when you add some chorizo and a couple of jalapeno peppers to the rice just before serving.

If you need to keep warm, then you need something that will keep going until you can get wood, if you are sitting around a fire all day, you will run out of fuel.
The most obvious answer is dry tinder, and there are many ways to make tinder out of things you find in the woods, from paper to cotton. The best accelerant for starting fires is #2 kerosene. If you are not comfortable with its use, you can use #1 or #4 gasoline. There are trade-offs in both cases, but both are still faster than using most alternative accelerants.
Kerosene is a great accelerant, and a poor fuel. It is low volatility, so it evaporates quickly, making it the fastest fuel to ignite (see the table in the Accelerant Speed page). Because it evaporates so fast, it is not very dense. In a 32 oz. container of #2 kerosene, there is about 17.5 lbs. of fuel, but only about 12.5 lbs. of it can be used as fuel. The rest is lost as vapor.

The past of eugenics

The best poisons are usually not the ones you need to worry about the effects of.
Not that I would recommend you do that, but one of the reasons why the real deal is a lot more dangerous than movie portrayals is that if you eat something, the onset of symptoms is often immediate, but if you're poisoned via a needle, you often don't feel a thing for up to a day.
